original_text: Historically, the interest in accurate measurement of DNI started decades ago. Early studies (e.g., Linke, 1931; Linke and Ulmitz, 1940) identified the difficulty of separating the measurement of DNI from that of the diffuse irradiance in the immediate vicinity of the sun, hereafter referred to as circumsolar irradiance. Pastiels (1959) conducted a detailed study of the geometry of pyrheliometers, and how that geometry interacted with circumsolar radiance, using simplified representations of the latter. Various communications were then presented at a WMO Task Group meeting held in Belgium in 1966 (WMO, 1967) to improve the accuracy of pyrheliometric measurements, including estimates of the circumsolar enhancement. Ångström (1961) and Ångström and Rohde (1966) later contributed to the same topic, followed years later by Major (1973, 1980). The whole issue of instrument geometry vs. circumsolar irradiance was complex and confusing at the time because different makes and models of instruments had differing geometries. This was considerably simplified after WMO issued guidelines about the recommended geometry of pyrheliometers, which led to a relatively standard geometry used in all recent instruments. The experimental issues related to the measurement of DNI are discussed in Section 3.2.
original_translation: Históricamente, el interés en la medición precisa de la DNI comenzó hace décadas. Estudios tempranos (por ejemplo, Linke, 1931; Linke y Ulmitz, 1940) identificaron la dificultad de separar la medición del DNI de la irradiancia difusa en las inmediaciones del sol, en adelante referida como irradiancia circumsolar. Pastiels (1959) realizó un estudio detallado de la geometría de los pirheliómetros y cómo esa geometría interactuaba con la radiación circumsolar, utilizando representaciones simplificadas de esta última. Varias comunicaciones fueron presentadas en una reunión del Grupo de Trabajo de la OMM celebrada en Bélgica en 1966 (OMM, 1967) para mejorar la precisión de las mediciones pireliométricas, incluyendo estimaciones del aumento circumsolar. Ångström (1961) y Ångström y Rohde (1966) contribuyeron más tarde al mismo tema, seguidos años después por Major (1973, 1980). El tema completo de la geometría del instrumento frente a la irradiancia circumsolar era complejo y confuso en ese momento porque diferentes marcas y modelos de instrumentos tenían geometrías diferentes. Esto se simplificó considerablemente después de que la OMM emitiera pautas sobre la geometría recomendada de los pirheliómetros, lo que llevó a una geometría relativamente estándar utilizada en todos los instrumentos recientes. Los problemas experimentales relacionados con la medición de DNI se discuten en la Sección 3.2.

Pastiels (1959) conducted a detailed study of the geometry of pyrheliometers, and how that geometry interacted with circumsolar radiance, using simplified representations of the latter.

Various communications were then presented at a WMO Task Group meeting held in Belgium in 1966 (WMO, 1967) to improve the accuracy of pyrheliometric measurements, including estimates of the circumsolar enhancement.

This was considerably simplified after WMO issued guidelines about the recommended geometry of pyrheliometers, which led to a relatively standard geometry used in all recent instruments.
The experimental issues related to the measurement of DNI are discussed in Section 3.2.
